section.heading: Scope.
section.text: This chapter sets forth additional requirements that a program shall meet as a private or public education program for individuals convicted under Transportation Article, §21-902, Annotated Code of Maryland, and ordered to attend an education program.

section.heading: Definitions.
section.text: In this chapter, terms have the meanings set forth in COMAR 10.47.01.02.

para.text: The applicant shall complete an application on a form approved by the Administration and submit the application and documentation to indicate the applicant is in compliance with the requirements of this chapter.
After the Administration receives the application the Administration shall:
Return the application if it is incomplete; or
Arrange a site visit.
After the site visit, the Administration shall
Grant approval;
Grant approval with conditions; or
Deny approval.
Comply with COMAR 10.47.01 and 10.47.02.03;
At minimum, offer six weekly 2-hour sessions for a total of 12 hours;
Have instructors approved by the Administration who are:
Instructors before October 1, 2002; or
At a minimum, certified as a Certified Supervised Counselor-Alcohol and Drug, as defined by Health Occupations Article, Title 17, Annotated Code of Maryland;
Ensure that staff is appropriately credentialed and privileged to teach the curriculum;
Teach the Administration's curriculum or an equivalent curriculum approved by the Administration, which covers:
Scope of drinking-driver problem;
Drinking driver patterns and characteristics;
The pharmacology of substance abuse;
The process of addiction to drugs and alcohol;
The relationship of substance use to crime, health, family, and other social problems; and
Treatment resources; and
Report to the court or probation agent as specified by the court order.

section.heading: Denial, Probation, Intermediate Sanctions, Suspension, or Revocation.

para.text: If an applicant or Program fails to comply with the applicable State and federal laws, rules, or regulations, the Director may:
Deny approval to the applicant; or
Take disciplinary action, such as:
Placing the program on probation;
Suspending or revoking the certification of the program; or
Imposing intermediate sanctions on the program.
For purposes of §A of this regulation, intermediate sanctions include:
A directed plan of correction, if the program is directed to take a specific action by a certain date;

A mandatory staffing pattern that is stricter than that required under the appropriate level of care in these regulations, if the Administration defines for the program the level of individual supervision;
Mandatory training, if the Administration identifies deficient areas in which training is needed;
Expansion ban, if the Administration retains the authority to prohibit the program from obtaining additional sites, admitting individuals, or providing additional services at the site;
Imposition of an intensive monitoring protocol by the Administration; or

Imposition of a temporary site monitor, if the Administration maintains an ongoing physical presence for the purpose of providing assistance and evaluating the extent of the program's corrective actions.

If the Director proposes to deny approval to an applicant or to take disciplinary action against a program, the Director shall give written notice to the health officer or executive director of the program.
In the written notice under §C of this regulation, the Director shall include:
The statutory and regulatory authority upon which the proposed action is based;
The facts supporting the alleged violation of law; and
The applicant's or program's right to a hearing before final action under §F of this regulation.
Summary Suspension.

Under the State Government Article, §10-226(c)(2), Annotated Code of Maryland, and if appropriate, after a predeprivation hearing, the Director may summarily order the suspension of the approval if the Administration finds that the public health, safety, or welfare imperatively requires emergency action.

The Director shall notify the program in writing of the suspension, findings, and reasons that support the findings, and, if appropriate, the opportunity for a predeprivation hearing. The notice shall include:
The proposed order for summary suspension which includes:
The statutory and regulatory authority upon which the order is based;
The facts supporting the alleged violations of law;
The facts supporting the belief that there is an imminent danger to the health, safety, and welfare of individuals; and
The program's right to appeal the summary suspension, if executed by the Director; and
A show cause notice providing an opportunity for the program to show cause as to why the order may not be issued if the public health, safety, and welfare permits.
The Director may suspend approval without prior notice and the opportunity to be heard if:
The Director determines that the health, welfare, and safety of the public imperatively requires immediate suspension;
Notice of an opportunity to be heard before the action is not feasible; and
The Administration provides the program with a post-deprivation hearing opportunity within 15 working days of the suspension.
Procedures for Hearings.
If the Director proposes to deny an approval or take disciplinary action against a program, the Director shall give the program written notice according to §C of this regulation.

Within 10 working days of receipt of the notice, the executive director or health officer may file a written request for a hearing with the Office of Administrative Hearings and send copies of the request to the:
Director; and
Administrative prosecutor.
If the executive director or health officer does not file a request for a hearing within 10 working days of receipt of the notification, the:
Program waives its right to request a hearing; and
Director may implement the proposed action.
If a timely request for a hearing has been received, the Office of Administrative Hearings shall:
Notify the Director, the executive director or health officer, and administrative prosecutor of the date, time, and location of the hearing; and
In accordance with COMAR 28.02.01, hold a hearing and, unless the final decision is delegated to the Office of Administrative Hearings, render a proposed decision to the Director.

After giving the parties the opportunity to file exceptions under the provisions of State Government Article, §10-216, Annotated Code of Maryland, the Director shall issue a final decision and send notice to the governing body or the health officer.

A program may appeal any final decision from a contested case by following the provisions of Health-General Article, §2-207, and State Government Article, Title 10, Subtitle 2, Annotated Code of Maryland.
In addition to disposing of a case by a hearing, the Director may dispose of a contested case by:
Stipulation;
Settlement;
Consent order;
Default;
Withdrawal;
Summary disposition; or
Dismissal.
